elements.content: By means of the in situ ligand formation strategy and hard–soft acid–base (HSAB) theory, two types of independent In­(COO)4 and Cu6S6 clusters were rationally embedded into the heterometallic metal–organic framework (HMOF) {[(CH3)2NH2]­InCu4L4·xS} n (BUT-52). BUT-52 exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) anionic framework structure and has sulfur decorating the dumbbell-shaped cages with the external edges of 24 and 14 Å by the internal edges. Remarkably, because of the stronger charge-induced interactions between the charged MOF skeleton and the easily polarized C2 hydrocarbons (C2s), BUT-52 was used for C2s over CH4 and shows both high adsorption heats of C2s and selective separation abilities for C2s/CH4. Furthermore, BUT-52 also displays efficient mercury adsorption resulting from the stronger-binding ability beween the sulfur and the mercury and can remove 92% mercury from methanol solution even with the initial concentration as low as 100 mg/L. The results in this work indicate the feasibility of BUT-52 for the separation of light hydrocarbons and efficient adsorption/removal of mercury.
elements.clean_text: By means of the in situ ligand formation strategy and hard-soft acid-base (HSAB) theory, two types of independent In(COO)4 and Cu6S6 clusters were rationally embedded into the heterometallic metal-organic framework (HMOF) {[(CH3)2NH2]InCu4L4⋅xS} n  (BUT-52). BUT-52 exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) anionic framework structure and has sulfur decorating the dumbbell-shaped cages with the external edges of 24 and 14 Å by the internal edges. Remarkably, because of the stronger charge-induced interactions between the charged MOF skeleton and the easily polarized C2 hydrocarbons (C2s), BUT-52 was used for C2s over CH4 and shows both high adsorption heats of C2s and selective separation abilities for C2s/CH4. Furthermore, BUT-52 also displays efficient mercury adsorption resulting from the stronger-binding ability beween the sulfur and the mercury and can remove 92% mercury from methanol solution even with the initial concentration as low as 100 mg/L. The results in this work indicate the feasibility of BUT-52 for the separation of light hydrocarbons and efficient adsorption/removal of mercury.

elements.content: Heterometallic metal–organic frameworks (HMOFs) based on distinct metal-containing building units are a class of newly developed MOFs with a wide range of potential application, especially in adsorption/separation. This modular nature endows well-tailored structures and the associated multiple functions within a single system. Compared with the efforts on the exploitation of suitable synthetic methods for the preparation of normal homometallic MOFs, the study of synthetic methodology on HMOFs is still at the early stage, a challenge yet. Postsynthetic coordination modification and direct/stepwise self-assembly based on mixed donor ligands, as well as metal ion/guest substitution, are dominant strategies for the preparation of HMOFs thus far. Generally, hard Lewis acid of metal ions preferentially coordinate the carboxylate (harder donor) groups of a mixed donor ligand while the softer donor groups (pyridyl N- or sulfhydryl S-centers) are available to bind soft Lewis acid of metal ions. Specifically, self-assembly method refers to a routine process that one or two functional groups immobilize one type of metal ion to in situ form a polyfunctional metalloligand and further cross-link the remaining metal ions, resulting in the extended monomer- or cluster-based HMOF.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Heterometallic metal-organic frameworks (HMOFs) based on distinct metal-containing building units are a class of newly developed MOFs with a wide range of potential application, especially in adsorption/separation. This modular nature endows well-tailored structures and the associated multiple functions within a single system. Compared with the efforts on the exploitation of suitable synthetic methods for the preparation of normal homometallic MOFs, the study of synthetic methodology on HMOFs is still at the early stage, a challenge yet. Postsynthetic coordination modification and direct/stepwise self-assembly based on mixed donor ligands, as well as metal ion/guest substitution, are dominant strategies for the preparation of HMOFs thus far. Generally, hard Lewis acid of metal ions preferentially coordinate the carboxylate (harder donor) groups of a mixed donor ligand while the softer donor groups (pyridyl N- or sulfhydryl S-centers) are available to bind soft Lewis acid of metal ions. Specifically, self-assembly method refers to a routine process that one or two functional groups immobilize one type of metal ion to in situ form a polyfunctional metalloligand and further cross-link the remaining metal ions, resulting in the extended monomer- or cluster-based HMOF.

elements.content: The in situ ligand formation, as one of the most powerful and efficient approaches, has been widely used in the design and preparation of functional MOFs. Such an approach denies the necessity of the ligand synthesis prior to the construction of MOFs. More importantly, it will decrease the reaction rate and further ensure the growth of single crystals sufficiently to allow single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD). Among them, the reductive cleavage of the S–S bonds has been explored as an attractive route to functional ligands and new MOFs or molecular clusters. Nevertheless, this method based on the in situ ligand formation is still not engaged in the preparation of HMOFs, to date.
elements.clean_text: The in situ ligand formation, as one of the most powerful and efficient approaches, has been widely used in the design and preparation of functional MOFs. Such an approach denies the necessity of the ligand synthesis prior to the construction of MOFs. More importantly, it will decrease the reaction rate and further ensure the growth of single crystals sufficiently to allow single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD). Among them, the reductive cleavage of the S-S bonds has been explored as an attractive route to functional ligands and new MOFs or molecular clusters. Nevertheless, this method based on the in situ ligand formation is still not engaged in the preparation of HMOFs, to date.

elements.content: Very recently, a 3D nanotubular Co2+/Na+-based HMOF (BUT-51, BUT = Beijing University of Technology) was synthesized in our group and was used in dye-selective adsorption and separation. In this work, by means of elaborate choice of reactants and hard–soft acid–base (HSAB) theory, we implemented the in situ ligand formation strategy and successfully synthesized an intriguing monomer- and cluster-based HMOF (), with the formula of {[(CH3)2NH2]­InCu4L4·xS} n (BUT-52, H2L = 6-mecaptopyridine-3-carboxylic, S represents unassigned free solvent molecules), which comprises classic In­(OOC)4 monomers and unique Cu6S6 clusters. It was found that the in situ synthesized trifunctional H2L is originated from 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid resulting from the cleavage of the S–S bond during the solvothermal reaction and further benefits the synthesis of BUT-52. Remarkably, because of the charged nature of BUT-52 and easily polarized C2 hydrocarbons (C2s), we further performed the charged HMOF for highly selective separation of C2s from C1 (CH4), where BUT-52 exhibits both high adsorption heats of C2s and selective separation abilities for C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 by the enhanced host–guest interactions through charge-induced forces. In addition, given the characterization of sulfur decorating the dumbbell-shaped cages, BUT-52 also shows efficient mercury adsorption because of the stronger-binding ability beween the sulfur and the mercury.
elements.clean_text: Very recently, a 3D nanotubular Co2+/Na+-based HMOF (BUT-51, BUT = Beijing University of Technology) was synthesized in our group and was used in dye-selective adsorption and separation. In this work, by means of elaborate choice of reactants and hard-soft acid-base (HSAB) theory, we implemented the in situ ligand formation strategy and successfully synthesized an intriguing monomer- and cluster-based HMOF (), with the formula of {[(CH3)2NH2]InCu4L4⋅xS} n  (BUT-52, H2L = 6-mecaptopyridine-3-carboxylic, S represents unassigned free solvent molecules), which comprises classic In(OOC)4 monomers and unique Cu6S6 clusters. It was found that the in situ synthesized trifunctional H2L is originated from 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid resulting from the cleavage of the S-S bond during the solvothermal reaction and further benefits the synthesis of BUT-52. Remarkably, because of the charged nature of BUT-52 and easily polarized C2 hydrocarbons (C2s), we further performed the charged HMOF for highly selective separation of C2s from C1 (CH4), where BUT-52 exhibits both high adsorption heats of C2s and selective separation abilities for C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 by the enhanced host-guest interactions through charge-induced forces. In addition, given the characterization of sulfur decorating the dumbbell-shaped cages, BUT-52 also shows efficient mercury adsorption because of the stronger-binding ability beween the sulfur and the mercury.

elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of the Rational Design of BUT-52 on the Basis of In3+, Cu+, and the in Situ Synthesized Ligand Involving Carboxylate, Pyridyl, and Thiol Groups

elements.content: Dark red polyhedral single crystals of BUT-52 were successfully prepared by heating the mixture of InCl3, CuI, and 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid in a 1:4:2 molar ratio in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA)/EtOH mixed solution at 120 °C for 12 h. The resultant framework formula of {[(CH3)2NH2]­InCu4L4·MeCN·H2O} n was defined from thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and elemental analysis (EA) after thorough treatment with CH3CN (see ). The anionic feature of the framework of BUT-52 was further confirmed by dye adsorption experiments. As expected, BUT-52 can rapidly adsorb cationic dye methylene blue (MB), but it does not adsorb the anionic dye, methyl orange (MO) (Figure S13). In addition, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirms that dye uptake occurs with the retention of the framework of BUT-52. Significantly, H2L and [(CH3)2NH2]+ should be generated from the decomposition of 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid and DMA, respectively. Furthermore, the synthesis of BUT-52 relies on subtle control over various experimental parameters, particularly the starting materials. For example, reaction of In­(NO3)3, CuI, and 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid could not form BUT-52, and a similar result occurs with the combination of InCl3, Cu­(ClO4)·4MeCN, and 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid. However, direct treatment of H2L, InCl3, and CuI could only produce unidentified amorphous solid. The results prove that the in situ ligand formation strategy based on slow formation of H2L via decomposition of 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid is critical for the synthesis of BUT-52. TGA of BUT-52 after thorough treatment with CH3CN revealed an initial weight loss of 6.1% up to 124 °C that is consistent with the loss of lattice CH3CN and H2O molecules. Above this temperature, a series of decomposition steps commence (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis, Characterization, Crystal Structure, and N2 Adsorption Property of BUT-52

Dark red polyhedral single crystals of BUT-52 were successfully prepared by heating the mixture of InCl3, CuI, and 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid in a 1:4:2 molar ratio in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA)/EtOH mixed solution at 120 °C for 12 h. The resultant framework formula of {[(CH3)2NH2]InCu4L4⋅MeCN⋅H2O} n  was defined from thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and elemental analysis (EA) after thorough treatment with CH3CN (see ). The anionic feature of the framework of BUT-52 was further confirmed by dye adsorption experiments. As expected, BUT-52 can rapidly adsorb cationic dye methylene blue (MB), but it does not adsorb the anionic dye, methyl orange (MO) (Figure S13). In addition, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirms that dye uptake occurs with the retention of the framework of BUT-52. Significantly, H2L and [(CH3)2NH2]+ should be generated from the decomposition of 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid and DMA, respectively. Furthermore, the synthesis of BUT-52 relies on subtle control over various experimental parameters, particularly the starting materials. For example, reaction of In(NO3)3, CuI, and 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid could not form BUT-52, and a similar result occurs with the combination of InCl3, Cu(ClO4)⋅4MeCN, and 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid. However, direct treatment of H2L, InCl3, and CuI could only produce unidentified amorphous solid. The results prove that the in situ ligand formation strategy based on slow formation of H2L via decomposition of 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid is critical for the synthesis of BUT-52. TGA of BUT-52 after thorough treatment with CH3CN revealed an initial weight loss of 6.1% up to 124 °C that is consistent with the loss of lattice CH3CN and H2O molecules. Above this temperature, a series of decomposition steps commence (Figure S2).

elements.content: SXRD analysis reveals that BUT-52 is a three-dimensional (3D) anionic framework structure and crystallizes in the cubic space group Pn-3m with cell parameters a = 22.0484(2) Å and V = 10718.43(17) Å3. The crystallographically asymmetric unit contains 1/8 In3+ ions, 1/2 Cu+ ions, and 1/2 L2– ligands as shown in Figure S1. The In3+ center exhibits an eight-coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry, binding with eight O atoms from four independent L2– ligands; the In–O bond lengths range from 2.218(3) to 2.314(3) Å. Cu+ ion is trigonal coordinated by one pyridyl N atom and two S atoms from three independent L2– ligands, where the observed Cu–S and Cu–N bond lengths are 2.251(10) and 2.052(4) Å, respectively. In the coordination environment of trifunctional L2– ligand, it utilizes a carboxylate group to chelate an eight-coordinated In3+ ion to constitute a classic 4-connected In­(COO)4 moiety, while it takes its remaining N- and S-donor centers to link three Cu+ ions to make a unique Cu6S6 cluster (a and b), which is very different from the reported analogues. The combination of one Cu6S6 and six L2– can be thus viewed as a novel hexadentate carboxylic ligand, typically a metalloligand (c). The solvent-accessible volume in BUT-52 estimated by PLATON is 67.4% of the total volume (potential solvent area volume = 7221.3 Å3; per unit cell volume = 10718.4 Å3), after removing all of the guest solvent molecules and [(CH3)2NH2]+. There are disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ accommodating the extra-large solvent accessible voids, which keep the charge balance. In this 3D structure (c), the interconnections of 12 [In­(COO)4] moieties and 8 Cu6S6 clusters via 28 L2– ligands define the sulfur-decorating dumbbell-shaped cage, and the following approximate sizes are observed: 24 Å by the external edges of two opposite Cu6S6 clusters and 14 Å by the internal edges of two opposite pyridine rings (a and b). Topologically, the [In­(COO)4] moiety serves as a 4-connected node, whereas [Cu6S6L6] metalligand can act as a 6-connecting node, by means of SYSTRE analysis thus leading to a (4,6)-connected toc net with a Schläfli symbol of (44.62)­(46.66.83) (d).

The crystallographically asymmetric unit contains 1/8 In3+ ions, 1/2 Cu+ ions, and 1/2 L2- ligands as shown in Figure S1. The In3+ center exhibits an eight-coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry, binding with eight O atoms from four independent L2- ligands; the In-O bond lengths  range from 2.218(3) to 2.314(3) Å. Cu+ ion is trigonal coordinated by one pyridyl N atom and two S atoms from three independent L2- ligands, where the observed Cu-S and Cu-N bond lengths are 2.251(10) and 2.052(4) Å, respectively. In the coordination environment of trifunctional L2- ligand, it  utilizes a carboxylate group to chelate an eight-coordinated In3+ ion to constitute a classic 4-connected In(COO)4 moiety, while it takes its remaining N- and S-donor centers to link three Cu+ ions to make  a unique Cu6S6 cluster (a and b), which is very different from the reported analogues. The combination of one Cu6S6 and six L2- can be thus viewed as a novel hexadentate carboxylic ligand, typically a metalloligand (c). The solvent-accessible volume in BUT-52 estimated by PLATON is 67.4% of the total volume (potential solvent area volume = 7221.3 Å3; per unit cell volume = 10718.4 Å3), after removing all of the guest solvent molecules and [(CH3)2NH2]+. There are disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ accommodating the extra-large solvent accessible voids, which keep the charge balance. In this 3D structure (c), the interconnections of 12 [In(COO)4] moieties and 8 Cu6S6 clusters via 28 L2- ligands define the sulfur-decorating dumbbell-shaped cage, and the following approximate sizes  are observed: 24 Å by the external edges of two opposite Cu6S6 clusters and 14 Å by the internal edges of two opposite pyridine rings (a and b). elements.content: (a) Highlighted coordination environment of L2– ligand. (b) 4-Connected In­(COO)4 monomer and unique Cu6S6 cluster. (c) The novel formed hexadentate metalloligand based on one Cu6S6 cluster and six L2– ligands. Color scheme: In, green; Cu, brown; S, yellow; N, blue; C, black; O, red. H atoms were omitted for clarity.

(c) The novel formed hexadentate metalloligand based on one Cu6S6 cluster and six L2- ligands. Color scheme: In, green; Cu, brown; S, yellow; N, blue; C, black; O, red. elements.content: (a, b) Top and side view of the dumbbell-shaped cage in BUT-52 (the radius of the caged sky-blue sphere is 7 Å). (c) 3D cage-based structure of BUT-52. (d) The simplification of the polymeric network in BUT-52 to the (4,6)-connected toc topology.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a, b) Top and side view of the dumbbell-shaped cage in BUT-52 (the radius of the caged sky-blue sphere is 7 Å). (c) 3D cage-based structure of BUT-52. (d) The simplification of the polymeric network in BUT-52 to the (4,6)-connected toc topology.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of BUT-52 was evaluated by N2 adsorption experiment at 77 K. After solvent-exchange with acetone, BUT-52 was activated and degassed under vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h, and it exhibited type-I N2 isotherm, characteristic of microporous nature with the saturated uptake of 126.2 cm3 g–1 (at P/P 0 = 0.95); Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (SBET) and Langmuir (SLangmuir) surface area are 358 m2 g–1 and 522 m2 g–1, respectively (Figure S3). The BET surface area of BUT-52 is 358 m2 g–1, probably because of the partially blocked voids induced by electrostatic attraction between disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ cations and anionic framework. Clearly, after N2 adsorption, BUT-52 keeps the intact structure skeleton, which is confirmed by PXRD (). Also, the CO2 uptake capacities are 57.9 and 26.5 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. At zero loading, the enthalpy of CO2 adsorption (Q st) is 25.1 kJ mol–1, as estimated from the sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K using the virial equation (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: The permanent porosity of BUT-52 was evaluated by N2 adsorption experiment at 77 K. After solvent-exchange with acetone, BUT-52 was activated and degassed under vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h, and it exhibited type-I N2 isotherm,  characteristic of microporous nature with the saturated uptake of 126.2 cm3 g-1 (at P/P 0 = 0.95);  Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (SBET) and Langmuir (SLangmuir) surface area are 358 m2 g-1 and 522 m2 g-1, respectively (Figure S3). The BET surface area of BUT-52 is 358 m2 g-1, probably because of the partially blocked voids induced by electrostatic attraction between disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ cations and anionic framework. Clearly, after N2 adsorption, BUT-52 keeps the intact structure skeleton, which is confirmed by PXRD (). Also, the CO2 uptake capacities are 57.9 and 26.5 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. At zero loading, the enthalpy of CO2 adsorption (Q st) is 25.1 kJ mol-1, as estimated from the sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K using the virial equation (Figure S4).

elements.content: PXRD patterns of BUT-52 after various treatments.
elements.clean_text: 3  PXRD patterns of BUT-52 after various treatments.

elements.content: Natural gas, consisting mainly of CH4, is a clean alternative energy source used in the chemical industry, and purification is prerequisite. The major impurities facing natural gas are C2s (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6). So, highly efficient separation of C2s over C1 (CH4) is required. Compared to traditional energy-intensive separation technologies, adsorptive separation using microporous MOF materials is widely considered as a more environment-friendly and energy-efficient alternative. Inspired by the robust nature and permanent porosity of BUT-52, we further investigated the uptake capacity of this MOF for light hydrocarbons. The maximal sorption values at ambient pressures for pure C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 are 86.7, 56.9, 71.6, and 13.2 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and are 71.6, 37.9, 40.7, and 7.7 cm3 g–1 at 298 K, respectively (a). Although the adsorbed amount of C2H2 in BUT-52 at 298 K is lower than those with high density of open-metal sites such as Cu-BTC (201 cm3 g–1), PCN-16 (176 cm3 g–1), and Zn-MOF-74 (122 cm3 g–1), the C2H2 uptake of BUT-52 at 298 K is comparable with MIL-53 (72 cm3 g–1), ZJU-31 (71.1 cm3 g–1), and Cu­(etz) (70 cm3 g–1) and is much higher than UTSA-36 (57 cm3 g–1), MOF-5 (26 cm3 g–1), and M’MOF-20 (21 cm3 g–1). The systematical adsorption capacities to CH4 of those of C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 at both 273 and 298 K further imply that BUT-52 may be a good candidate material for the separation of C2s from CH4.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrocarbon Adsorption Isotherms, Calculations of Selectivities Based on  Henry's Law, Selectivity and Isosteric Heats of Gas Adsorption (Q st)

Natural gas, consisting mainly of CH4, is a clean alternative energy source used in the chemical industry, and purification is prerequisite. The major impurities facing natural gas are C2s (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6). So, highly efficient separation of C2s over C1 (CH4) is required. Compared to traditional energy-intensive separation technologies, adsorptive separation using microporous MOF materials is widely considered as a more environment-friendly and energy-efficient alternative. Inspired by the robust nature and permanent porosity of BUT-52, we further investigated the uptake capacity of this MOF for light hydrocarbons. The maximal sorption values at ambient pressures for pure C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 are 86.7, 56.9, 71.6, and 13.2 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and are 71.6, 37.9, 40.7, and 7.7 cm3 g-1 at 298 K, respectively (a). Although the adsorbed amount of C2H2 in BUT-52 at 298 K is lower than those with high density of open-metal sites such as Cu-BTC (201 cm3 g-1), PCN-16 (176 cm3 g-1), and Zn-MOF-74 (122 cm3 g-1), the C2H2 uptake of BUT-52 at 298 K is comparable with MIL-53 (72 cm3 g-1), ZJU-31 (71.1 cm3 g-1), and Cu(etz) (70 cm3 g-1) and is much higher than UTSA-36 (57 cm3 g-1), MOF-5 (26 cm3 g-1), and M'MOF-20 (21 cm3 g-1). The systematical adsorption capacities to CH4 of those of C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 at both 273 and 298 K further imply that BUT-52 may be a good candidate material for the separation of C2s from CH4.

elements.content: (a) C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K. (b) The isosteric heats of adsorption of C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 on BUT-52.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K. (b) The isosteric heats of adsorption of C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 on BUT-52.

elements.content: To evaluate the adsorption selectivity of light hydrocarbons, the separation ratios of C2s over CH4 are calculated by Henry’s law. Henry’s law selectivity for gas component i over j at a specific temperature is calculated on the basis of the following equation: S ij = K Hi / K Hj Henry’s law constants were calculated directly from the adsorption isotherms. The results show that the selectivities for C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 at 273 K, respectively, are 36.4, 20.5, and 15.5 and at 298 K are 23.5, 14.4, and 13.7. Notable, BUT-52 displays a great separation ratio of C2H2/CH4, in excess of 23 at 298 K, which is much higher than those of MOFs with high-density open-metal sites UTSA-33a (17.1), Cu­(BDC–OH) (9.3), and (H3O)4[Ni6(μ3-O)2(μ2-OSC2H6)2(SO4)2(TATB)8/3]·4C2H6O·13H2O (14.1) and which is comparable to that of ZJU-31 (23.4). (Some virial parameters are summarized in Table S3.) In addition, the separation ratios of CO2 versus CH4 and N2 are also given, and detailed information is provided in Figures S9–11.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the adsorption selectivity of light hydrocarbons, the separation ratios of C2s over CH4 are calculated by  Henry's law. Henry's law selectivity for gas component i over j at a specific temperature is calculated on the basis of the following equation:      S   ij   =   K   Hi   /   K   Hj     Henry's law constants were calculated directly from the adsorption isotherms. The results show that the selectivities for C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 at 273 K, respectively, are 36.4, 20.5, and 15.5 and at 298 K are 23.5, 14.4, and 13.7. Notable, BUT-52 displays a great separation ratio of C2H2/CH4, in excess of 23 at 298 K, which is much higher than those of MOFs with high-density open-metal sites UTSA-33a (17.1), Cu(BDC-OH) (9.3), and (H3O)4[Ni6(μ3-O)2(μ2-OSC2H6)2(SO4)2(TATB)8/3]⋅4C2H6O⋅13H2O (14.1) and which is comparable to that of ZJU-31 (23.4). (Some virial parameters are summarized in Table S3.) In addition, the separation ratios of CO2 versus CH4 and N2 are also given, and  detailed information is provided in Figures S9-11.

elements.content: To illuminate why BUT-52 shows selective separation for light hydrocarbons, the isosteric heat of adsorption, Q st, defined as Q st = R T 2 ( ∂ ⁡ ln ⁡ p ∂ T ) q was determined using the pure component isotherm fits. The isosteric heat (Q st) values of C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 at zero coverage are 35.5, 27.3, 31.8, and 19.0 kJ mol–1, respectively (b). The calculated results show the hierarchy of adsorption capacity is commonly CH4 < C2H4 < C2H6 < C2H2, indicating the feasibility of BUT-52 for the separation of light hydrocarbons. The systematically higher adsorption heats of C2s and selectivies of C2s/CH4 can be probably attributed to the stronger charge-induced van der Waals interactions between the charged framework skeleton of BUT-52 and the easily polarized C2s. These results confirm the promising separation of CH4 from mixtures containing C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 species, that is, potential application for BUT-52 in the purification of natural gas.
elements.clean_text: To illuminate why BUT-52 shows selective separation for light hydrocarbons, the isosteric heat of adsorption, Q st, defined as      Q   st   = R   T   2     (   ∂ ⁡ ln ⁡ p   ∂ T   )   q     was determined using the pure component isotherm fits. The isosteric heat (Q st) values of C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 at zero coverage are 35.5, 27.3, 31.8, and 19.0 kJ mol-1, respectively (b). The calculated results show the hierarchy of adsorption capacity is commonly CH4 < C2H4 < C2H6 < C2H2, indicating the feasibility of BUT-52 for the separation of light hydrocarbons. The systematically higher adsorption heats of C2s and selectivies of C2s/CH4 can be probably attributed to the stronger charge-induced van der Waals interactions between the charged framework skeleton of BUT-52 and the easily polarized C2s. These results confirm the promising separation of CH4 from mixtures containing C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 species, that is, potential application for BUT-52 in the purification of natural gas.

elements.content: Because of the advantages of the stronger-binding ability between sulfur atoms and diverse metal ions, the incorporation of the very reactive sulfur atoms into MOFs becomes very popular and is often studied for efficient metal ion removal/separation applications, especially for mercury adsorption. Notably, He et al. utilized thioether-anchored Zn4O·(L)3·(DMF)4·(H2O)4 (H2L = 2,5-bis­(2-(methylthio)­ethylthio)­terephthalic acid) to take up HgCl2 from an ethanol solution at a concentration as low as 84 mg/L. Shortly afterward, the thiol-laced Zr-DMBD (H2DMBD = 2,5-dimercapto-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) crystals lowering the Hg2+ concentration in water below 0.01 ppm and effectively taking up Hg from the vapor phase was reported in the same group. On the basis of the characterization of sulfur decorating the dumbbell-shaped cages in BUT-52, the exploration of its application for mercury adsorption seems to be promising.
elements.clean_text:
Procedure and Characterization of Mercury Adsorption

Because of the advantages of the stronger-binding ability between sulfur atoms and diverse metal ions, the incorporation of the very reactive sulfur atoms into MOFs becomes very popular and is often studied for efficient metal ion removal/separation applications, especially for mercury adsorption. Notably, He et al. utilized thioether-anchored Zn4O⋅(L)3⋅(DMF)4⋅(H2O)4 (H2L = 2,5-bis(2-(methylthio)ethylthio)terephthalic acid) to take up HgCl2 from an ethanol solution at a concentration as low as 84 mg/L. Shortly afterward, the thiol-laced Zr-DMBD (H2DMBD = 2,5-dimercapto-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) crystals lowering the Hg2+ concentration in water below 0.01 ppm and effectively taking up Hg from the vapor phase was reported in the same group. On the basis of the characterization of sulfur decorating the dumbbell-shaped cages in BUT-52, the exploration of its application for mercury adsorption seems to be promising.

elements.content: To assess the mercury adsorption capacity, freshly prepared BUT-52 crystal sample (∼15 mg) was immersed in a methanol solution of HgCl2 (0.1 M, 3.0 mL). After being stirred for about 12 h at room temperature, the crystals turned from dark red into brown yellow ( insert). The solid was then isolated by centrifugation and was further thoroughly washed with methanol to remove residual HgCl2 on the surface of the sample. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) revealed that both the elements of Hg and Cl are obviously located in the resulting sample (denoted as BUT-52·HgCl2) (Figure S14). Inspired by this, the chemical composition and the In/Cu/Ag ratio of BUT-52·HgCl2 were further determined by elemental analysis (EA), TGA, and atomic absorption spectrophotometer (AAS) analysis, leading to a molecular formula of {[(CH3)2NH2]­InCu4L4·1.28HgCl2·2MeOH·0.5H2O} n . In addition, after mercury adsorption, BUT-52 keeps its original framework skeleton, which was confirmed by PXRD (). Further, the adsorptive mechanism was revealed by Raman spectrum of BUT-52·HgCl2, showing a strong characteristic band at 353 cm–1, consistent with the stretch of Hg–S bond (355 cm–1), which is absent in the spectrum of BUT-52 (). Notably, other metal ions (Pb2+, Cu2+, Pd2+, and Ag+) having stronger binding abilities with sulfur atoms do not affect the dark red color of the crystal samples after a 12 h stirring (the crystals of BUT-52 are decomposed in a methanol solution of Ag+). EDS demonstrated that negligible contents of Pd and Pb are in the resulting samples (Figure S15). In addition, AAS analysis revealed an approximate In/Cu ratio of 1:4 in the final sample in a methanol solution of Cu2+, indicating that there is no obvious uptake toward Cu2+ as well. These results may show a mercury-exclusive adsorption in BUT-52 and further suggest no effects of other metal ions on the removal of mercury.
elements.clean_text: To assess the mercury adsorption capacity, freshly prepared BUT-52 crystal sample (~15 mg) was immersed in a methanol solution of HgCl2 (0.1 M, 3.0 mL). After being stirred for about 12 h at room temperature, the crystals turned from dark red into brown yellow ( insert). The solid was then isolated by centrifugation and was further thoroughly washed with methanol to remove residual HgCl2 on the surface of the sample. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) revealed that both the elements of Hg and Cl are obviously located in the resulting sample (denoted as BUT-52⋅HgCl2) (Figure S14). Inspired by this, the chemical composition and the In/Cu/Ag ratio of BUT-52⋅HgCl2 were further determined by elemental analysis (EA), TGA, and atomic absorption spectrophotometer (AAS) analysis, leading to a molecular formula of {[(CH3)2NH2]InCu4L4⋅1.28HgCl2⋅2MeOH⋅0.5H2O} n . In addition, after mercury adsorption, BUT-52 keeps its original framework skeleton, which was confirmed by PXRD (). Further, the adsorptive mechanism was revealed by Raman spectrum of BUT-52⋅HgCl2, showing a strong characteristic band at 353 cm-1, consistent with the stretch of Hg-S bond (355 cm-1), which is absent in the spectrum of BUT-52 (). Notably, other metal ions (Pb2+, Cu2+, Pd2+, and Ag+) having stronger binding abilities with sulfur atoms do not affect the dark red color of the crystal samples after a 12 h stirring (the crystals of BUT-52 are decomposed in a methanol solution of Ag+). EDS demonstrated that negligible contents of Pd and Pb are in the resulting samples (Figure S15). In addition, AAS analysis revealed an approximate In/Cu ratio of 1:4 in the final sample in a methanol solution of Cu2+, indicating that there is no obvious uptake toward Cu2+ as well. These results may show a mercury-exclusive adsorption in BUT-52 and further suggest no effects of other metal ions on the removal of mercury.

elements.content: Raman spectra of as-synthesized sample of BUT-52 (dark red) and HgCl2 treated BUT-52 sample (brown yellow).
elements.clean_text: 5  Raman spectra of as-synthesized sample of BUT-52 (dark red) and HgCl2 treated BUT-52 sample (brown yellow).

elements.content: Furthermore, we performed the effective capture of mercury in a low concentration from methanol. An as-prepared BUT-52 sample (∼15 mg) was added in a dilute methanol solution (3 mL) of HgCl2 with the initial concentration of 100 mg/L. After the mixture was stirred at RT for 12 h, the residual amount of HgCl2 in the solution was decreased to ∼8 mg/L, indicating over 92% of the HgCl2 was thus removed by BUT-52. The removal efficiency of BUT-52 is lower than that of Zr-DMBD with thiol function (>99.9%), which is comparable with thioether-anchored Zn4O·(L)3·(DMF)4·(H2O)4 (>94%). These results indicate that BUT-52 may be a good candidate for efficient mercury adsorption and removal.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, we performed the effective capture of mercury in a low concentration from methanol. An as-prepared BUT-52 sample (~15 mg) was added in a dilute methanol solution (3 mL) of HgCl2 with the initial concentration of 100 mg/L. After the mixture was stirred at RT for 12 h, the residual amount of HgCl2 in the solution was decreased to ~8 mg/L, indicating over 92% of the HgCl2 was thus removed by BUT-52. The removal efficiency of BUT-52 is lower than that of Zr-DMBD with thiol function (>99.9%), which is comparable with thioether-anchored Zn4O⋅(L)3⋅(DMF)4⋅(H2O)4 (>94%). These results indicate that BUT-52 may be a good candidate for efficient mercury adsorption and removal.

elements.content: In summary, by means of the in situ ligand formation strategy and HSAB theory, a novel anionic HMOF of BUT-52 with sulfur decorating the dumbbell-shaped cages was rationally designed and synthesized. It was found that this MOF exhibits high adsorption heats of C2s and selective separation of C2s over CH4, the mechanism of which might be due to the enhanced host–guest electrostatic interactions between the charged HMOF framework and the more polarized C2s. In addition, BUT-52 shows efficient mercury adsorption by the stronger-binding ability beween the sulfur and the mercury. The realizations in this work initiate the extensive exploration of emerging aspects toward a unique synthesis approach and potential applications of HMOFs. A research endeavor toward the rational design and synthesis of functional HMOFs for adsorption and separation is in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, by means of the in situ ligand formation strategy and HSAB theory, a novel anionic HMOF of BUT-52 with sulfur decorating the dumbbell-shaped cages was rationally designed and synthesized. It was found that this MOF exhibits high adsorption heats of C2s and selective separation of C2s over CH4, the mechanism of which might be due to the enhanced host-guest electrostatic interactions between the charged HMOF framework and the more polarized C2s. In addition, BUT-52 shows efficient mercury adsorption by the stronger-binding ability beween the sulfur and the mercury. The realizations in this work initiate the extensive exploration of emerging aspects toward a unique synthesis approach and potential applications of HMOFs. A research endeavor toward the rational design and synthesis of functional HMOFs for adsorption and separation is in progress.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1 on a Shimadzu IR435 spectrometer. A FLASH EA 1112 analyzer was performed for the elemental analysis. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer between 30 and 800 °C and a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were measured on the PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer using Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.541874 Å). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) was performed on a Bruker ISMNM 761 scanning electron microscope. A Z28000 graphite-oven atomic absorption spectrophotometer (AAS) was employed to determine the amount of metal ions. Raman spectra were acquired on a Renishaw inVia system. N2, CO2, CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 adsorption/desorption data were measured on an ASAP 2020 surface area analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instruments

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Shimadzu IR435 spectrometer. A FLASH EA 1112 analyzer was performed for the elemental analysis. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer between 30 and 800 °C and a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were measured on the PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.541874 Å). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) was performed on a Bruker ISMNM 761 scanning electron microscope. A Z28000 graphite-oven atomic absorption spectrophotometer (AAS) was employed to determine the amount of metal ions. Raman spectra were acquired on a Renishaw inVia system. N2, CO2, CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 adsorption/desorption data were measured on an ASAP 2020 surface area analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of InCl3·4H2O (15 mg, 0.05 mmol), CuI (38 mg, 0.2 mmol), and 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid (31 mg, 0.1 mmol) dissolved in DMA (2 mL) and EtOH (2 mL) was heated at 120 °C for 12 h. Dark red polyhedral crystals of BUT-52 in 56% yield (based on InCl3·4H2O) accompanied by unreacted CuI were harvested. As-synthesized BUT-52 was immersed in CH3CN for 3 days (change fresh CH3CN every 12 h) and was thoroughly washed by CH3CN to remove excess CuI. BUT-52 was found to be insoluble in common organic solvents, but it decomposed in water. EA calcd (%) for C28H25Cu4InN6O9S4: C, 30.94; H, 2.32; N, 7.73. Found: C, 31.17; H, 2.02; N, 7.82.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[(CH3)2NH2]InCu4L4⋅MeCN⋅H2O} n  (BUT-52)

A mixture of InCl3⋅4H2O (15 mg, 0.05 mmol), CuI (38 mg, 0.2 mmol), and 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid (31 mg, 0.1 mmol) dissolved in DMA (2 mL) and EtOH (2 mL) was heated at 120 °C for 12 h. Dark red polyhedral crystals of BUT-52 in 56% yield (based on InCl3⋅4H2O) accompanied by unreacted CuI were harvested. As-synthesized BUT-52 was immersed in CH3CN for 3 days (change fresh CH3CN every 12 h) and was thoroughly washed by CH3CN to remove excess CuI. BUT-52 was found to be insoluble in common organic solvents, but it decomposed in water. EA calcd (%) for C28H25Cu4InN6O9S4: C, 30.94; H, 2.32; N, 7.73. Found: C, 31.17; H, 2.02; N, 7.82.

elements.content:
The procedures were performed following our recently published work, except the as-synthesized sample of BUT-52 was first immersed and thoroughly washed by fresh CH3CN.

Mercury Adsorption

Freshly prepared BUT-52 sample (15 mg) was immersed in a methanol solution of HgCl2 (0.1 M, 3.0 mL). After being stirred for about 12 h at room temperature, the crystals turned from dark red into brown yellow. The resulting crystals formulated as {[(CH3)2NH2]­InCu4L4·1.28HgCl2·2MeOH·0.5H2O} n (designated as BUT-52·HgCl2) were isolated by centrifugation and were thoroughly washed by methanol to remove residual HgCl2 on the surface of the sample. AAS analysis revealed an approximate In/Cu/Hg ratio of 1:4:1.28 (In, Cu, and Hg concentrations found: 57.1, 132.4, and 125.7 mg/g, respectively). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C29H30Cu4InHg1.28N6O10.5S4Cl2.56: C, 23.61; H, 3.05; N, 5.70. Found: C, 23.97; H, 3.97; N, 5.43.
elements.clean_text:
Activation of the Sample

The procedures were performed following our recently published work, except the as-synthesized sample of BUT-52 was first immersed and thoroughly washed by fresh CH3CN.

Mercury Adsorption

Freshly prepared BUT-52 sample (15 mg) was immersed in a methanol solution of HgCl2 (0.1 M, 3.0 mL). After being stirred for about 12 h at room temperature, the crystals turned from dark red into brown yellow. The resulting crystals formulated as {[(CH3)2NH2]InCu4L4⋅1.28HgCl2⋅2MeOH⋅0.5H2O} n  (designated as BUT-52⋅HgCl2) were isolated by centrifugation and were thoroughly washed by methanol to remove residual HgCl2 on the surface of the sample. AAS analysis revealed an approximate In/Cu/Hg ratio of 1:4:1.28 (In, Cu, and Hg concentrations found: 57.1, 132.4, and 125.7 mg/g, respectively). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C29H30Cu4InHg1.28N6O10.5S4Cl2.56: C, 23.61; H, 3.05; N, 5.70. Found: C, 23.97; H, 3.97; N, 5.43.

elements.content: Data collection for BUT-52 was carried on an Agilent Technologies SuperNova Single Crystal Diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 100 K. The structure was solved using SHELXS-97 and was refined with SHELXL-97. The hydrogen atoms were included in the structure-factor calculations at idealized positions by using a riding model and were refined isotropically. The contributions of guests were removed by using SQUEEZE as implemented in PLATON. CCDC-1057212 (BUT-52) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. Crystal data and the selected bond lengths and angles for BUT-52 are summarized in Tables S1 and S2.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Crystallography

Data collection for BUT-52 was carried on an Agilent Technologies SuperNova Single Crystal Diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 100 K. The structure was solved using SHELXS-97 and was refined with SHELXL-97. The hydrogen atoms were included in the structure-factor calculations at idealized positions by using a riding model and were refined isotropically. The contributions of guests were removed by using SQUEEZE as implemented in PLATON. CCDC-1057212 (BUT-52) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. Crystal data and the selected bond lengths and angles for BUT-52 are summarized in Tables S1 and S2.

cln_elements.content:
SXRD analysis reveals that BUT-52 is a three-dimensional (3D) anionic framework structure and crystallizes in the cubic space group Pn-3m with cell parameters a = 22.0484(2) Å and V = 10718.43(17) Å3. The crystallographically asymmetric unit contains 1/8 In3+ ions, 1/2 Cu+ ions, and 1/2 L2– ligands as shown in Figure S1. The In3+ center exhibits an eight-coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry, binding with eight O atoms from four independent L2– ligands; the In–O bond lengths range from 2.218(3) to 2.314(3) Å. Cu+ ion is trigonal coordinated by one pyridyl N atom and two S atoms from three independent L2– ligands, where the observed Cu–S and Cu–N bond lengths are 2.251(10) and 2.052(4) Å, respectively. In the coordination environment of trifunctional L2– ligand, it utilizes a carboxylate group to chelate an eight-coordinated In3+ ion to constitute a classic 4-connected In­(COO)4 moiety, while it takes its remaining N- and S-donor centers to link three Cu+ ions to make a unique Cu6S6 cluster (a and b), which is very different from the reported analogues. The combination of one Cu6S6 and six L2– can be thus viewed as a novel hexadentate carboxylic ligand, typically a metalloligand (c). The solvent-accessible volume in BUT-52 estimated by PLATON is 67.4% of the total volume (potential solvent area volume = 7221.3 Å3; per unit cell volume = 10718.4 Å3), after removing all of the guest solvent molecules and [(CH3)2NH2]+. There are disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ accommodating the extra-large solvent accessible voids, which keep the charge balance. In this 3D structure (c), the interconnections of 12 [In­(COO)4] moieties and 8 Cu6S6 clusters via 28 L2– ligands define the sulfur-decorating dumbbell-shaped cage, and the following approximate sizes are observed: 24 Å by the external edges of two opposite Cu6S6 clusters and 14 Å by the internal edges of two opposite pyridine rings (a and b). Topologically, the [In­(COO)4] moiety serves as a 4-connected node, whereas [Cu6S6L6] metalligand can act as a 6-connecting node, by means of SYSTRE analysis thus leading to a (4,6)-connected toc net with a Schläfli symbol of (44.62)­(46.66.83) (d).

The permanent porosity of BUT-52 was evaluated by N2 adsorption experiment at 77 K. After solvent-exchange with acetone, BUT-52 was activated and degassed under vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h, and it exhibited type-I N2 isotherm, characteristic of microporous nature with the saturated uptake of 126.2 cm3 g–1 (at P/P 0 = 0.95); Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (SBET) and Langmuir (SLangmuir) surface area are 358 m2 g–1 and 522 m2 g–1, respectively (Figure S3). The BET surface area of BUT-52 is 358 m2 g–1, probably because of the partially blocked voids induced by electrostatic attraction between disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ cations and anionic framework. Clearly, after N2 adsorption, BUT-52 keeps the intact structure skeleton, which is confirmed by PXRD (). Also, the CO2 uptake capacities are 57.9 and 26.5 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. At zero loading, the enthalpy of CO2 adsorption (Q st) is 25.1 kJ mol–1, as estimated from the sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K using the virial equation (Figure S4).
cln_elements.clean_text:
SXRD analysis reveals that BUT-52 is a three-dimensional (3D) anionic framework structure and crystallizes in the cubic space group Pn-3m with cell parameters a = 22.0484(2) Å and V = 10718.43(17) Å3. The crystallographically asymmetric unit contains 1/8 In3+ ions, 1/2 Cu+ ions, and 1/2 L2- ligands as shown in Figure S1. The In3+ center exhibits an eight-coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry, binding with eight O atoms from four independent L2- ligands; the In-O bond lengths  range from 2.218(3) to 2.314(3) Å. Cu+ ion is trigonal coordinated by one pyridyl N atom and two S atoms from three independent L2- ligands, where the observed Cu-S and Cu-N bond lengths are 2.251(10) and 2.052(4) Å, respectively. In the coordination environment of trifunctional L2- ligand, it  utilizes a carboxylate group to chelate an eight-coordinated In3+ ion to constitute a classic 4-connected In(COO)4 moiety, while it takes its remaining N- and S-donor centers to link three Cu+ ions to make  a unique Cu6S6 cluster (a and b), which is very different from the reported analogues. The combination of one Cu6S6 and six L2- can be thus viewed as a novel hexadentate carboxylic ligand, typically a metalloligand (c). The solvent-accessible volume in BUT-52 estimated by PLATON is 67.4% of the total volume (potential solvent area volume = 7221.3 Å3; per unit cell volume = 10718.4 Å3), after removing all of the guest solvent molecules and [(CH3)2NH2]+. There are disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ accommodating the extra-large solvent accessible voids, which keep the charge balance. In this 3D structure (c), the interconnections of 12 [In(COO)4] moieties and 8 Cu6S6 clusters via 28 L2- ligands define the sulfur-decorating dumbbell-shaped cage, and the following approximate sizes  are observed: 24 Å by the external edges of two opposite Cu6S6 clusters and 14 Å by the internal edges of two opposite pyridine rings (a and b). Topologically, the [In(COO)4] moiety serves as a 4-connected node, whereas [Cu6S6L6] metalligand can act as a 6-connecting node, by means of SYSTRE analysis thus leading to a (4,6)-connected toc net with a Schläfli symbol of (44.62)(46.66.83) (d).

The permanent porosity of BUT-52 was evaluated by N2 adsorption experiment at 77 K. After solvent-exchange with acetone, BUT-52 was activated and degassed under vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h, and it exhibited type-I N2 isotherm,  characteristic of microporous nature with the saturated uptake of 126.2 cm3 g-1 (at P/P 0 = 0.95);  Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (SBET) and Langmuir (SLangmuir) surface area are 358 m2 g-1 and 522 m2 g-1, respectively (Figure S3). The BET surface area of BUT-52 is 358 m2 g-1, probably because of the partially blocked voids induced by electrostatic attraction between disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ cations and anionic framework. Clearly, after N2 adsorption, BUT-52 keeps the intact structure skeleton, which is confirmed by PXRD (). Also, the CO2 uptake capacities are 57.9 and 26.5 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. At zero loading, the enthalpy of CO2 adsorption (Q st) is 25.1 kJ mol-1, as estimated from the sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K using the virial equation (Figure S4).

metadata.title:
In-Situ
Ligand Formation-Driven Preparation of a Heterometallic Metal–Organic
